results.title: Library of Congress
results.creator_credit: United States. Office of War Information
results.brief_description:
Episode number 11 of Series “The American Scene”.
An account of the scope and methods of operation of the Library of Congress at Washington. Science, painting, music, literature and history are shown as some of the interests of the Institution. The library’s contents include valuable historical documents, newsreel records of outstanding events and personalities, Braille and talking books (on disc) for the blind, in addition to much material of general public interest. Includes a concert performance of music from manuscript collection and library staff in the field recording little known folk musicians.

results.title: A Better tomorrow
results.creator_credit: United States. Office of War Information
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “The American Scene”.
A study of progressive education in three schools in New York, where the emphasis of teaching is placed on the fact that learning is a normal and vital part of every child’s day-to-day development; what the child is taught in school should therefore bear a discernible relation to the world around the child, and be a challlenge to their increasing skills and expanding understanding of how to manipulate the things whcih surround them.

results.title: The Novel and television
results.creator_credit: Alasdair Clayre, Open University and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The 19th Century Novel”.
A discussion on some of the differences between the novel in its television dramatised form and the original prose. The film uses the problems involved in dramatisation as a way of discussing the novels concerned. The novels dealt with are Cousin Bette and Great Expectations.

group_siblings.title: Virginia Woolf's criticism of the novel 'Life escapes'

results.title: Tolstoy after Anna Karenina
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The 19th Century Novel”.
After publishing Anna Karenina Tolstoy suffered a crisis in his personal and public life. The question which in Anna Karenina haunts Levin “Why am I?” became more and more urgent to Tolstoy and his answers became more extreme. He was a man who craved solitude, but his admirers almost made this impossible for him. Tolstoy died on 7 November 1910. Documentary also features Russian writers Godky and Chekov. Uses archival footage and stills.

results.title: Virginia Woolf's criticism of the novel 'Life escapes'
results.creator_credit: Richard Callanan, Open University and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The 19th Century Novel”.
Following a dramatised scene from Virginia Woolf’s novel “Life Escapes”, Professor Arnold Kettle argues that Virginia Woolf was not just telling a story but recreating an era of reality and this leads her to break with the traditional form of the novel in a way which emphasises the moment-to-moment impressions of life.
results.title_for_label: Virginia Woolf’s criticism of the novel ‘Life escapes’

results.title: Forster and Lawrence
results.creator_credit: Alasdair Clayre and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The 19th Century Novel”.
Richard Hoggart discusses with Graham Martin the contrast between the prose style of D.H. Lawrence and E.M. Forster, with particular reference to the “Fox” and “Where Angels Fear to Tread”.

group_works.title: Harvest at Nong Lub
group_works.creator_credit: Brian Hannant, Thanom Soongnarata, John Morris and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: Harvest at Nong Lub
results.creator_credit: Brian Hannant, Thanom Soongnarata, John Morris and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Thailand”.
Without intruding, an Australian camera crew lives with a Thai family during the rice harvest. The comings and goings, the hard work, the moments of relaxation, the dreams and also the aspirations are briefly held in the hope of understanding the differences in life and the similarities in being
